summary: The U.S. District Court for the Central District of California on May 7, 2019, entered a temporary restraining order against the issuance of immigration detainers to state and local law enforcement agencies that lack authority for civil immigration enforcement.  According to the SEC's complaint, from 2012 to 2016, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) issued an immigration detainer to certain individuals in violation of the federal immigration laws.  The complaint alleges that the detainer was based on information that was not available to the agency at the time it issued it.  In addition, the complaint alleged that ICE failed to adequately check the accuracy of the databases it uses to determine whether a person has been removed from the country.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, ICE has consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining it from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, as well as the reporting provisions of Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4), and that the court will determine the amount of disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties to be determined by the court upon motion of the SEC.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 1373:11-13 (D.C. 2013).  The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted by Jennifer Pasquarella and John J. W. Inkeles of the United States Department of Justice, and the litigation will be led by Daniel J. Messerschmidt and supervised by Lara S. Mehraban. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Los Angeles Police Department, the Internal Revenue Service Criminal Investigations, the Department of Homeland Security, the FBI, the California Office of Inspector General, the Federal Housing Finance Agency, the Texas Department of Banking and Securities, the Arizona Department of Insurance, the USCIS Office of Immigrant Affairs, the San Diego Police Department and the California Department of Attorney General's Office. The case is being supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay, Chief of the Enforcement Division's Home Office.
